choices.D: validates the content of a candidate datastore
choices.B: uses the YANG data models to communicate

questions.question_text: Which function is available in NETCONF and unavailable in RESTCONF?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D - Candidate configurations

"Once you understand REST and NETCONF individually, RESTCONF becomes much easier to understand. RESTCONF, in simplest terms, adds a REST API to NETCONF. YANG models are used with RESTCONF; the URLs, HTTP verbs, and request bodies are automatically generated from the associated YANG model. Unlike NETCONF, RESTCONF supports both XML and JSON. RESTCONF is a subset of NETCONF, so not all operations are supported, for example candidate configurations."

questions.question_text: Which setting is used for the dampening period when configuring an on-change publication for YANG-push versus OpenConfig?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
On-Change Publication for yang-push
When creating an on-change subscription, the dampening period must be set to 0 to indicate that there is no dampening period; no other value is supported.

Selected Answer: AC
its A C

questions.question_text:
Setting is used for the dampening period when configuring an on-change publication for YANG-push versus OpenConfig.
What are two characteristics of synchronous calls to APIs? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Calls are limited to specific programming languages
choices.E: They do not block while waiting for the API to be processed
choices.A: They block until a response is returned from the servers
choices.C: They add perceived latency to an application if data is not received
choices.B: They make an application less portable, so asynchronous calls are preferred

discussion.content:
The snippet shows:
-Two containers: interfaces, statistics. 
-Two leaf-list: higher-layer-if, lower-layer-if
-Nine optional metrics (all that start with ?)
Answer B
Source:https://yangcatalog.org/yang-search/yang_tree/Cisco-IOS-XE-interfaces-oper@2019-11-01

comments.content: isn't is 10 optional metrics? Still, I agree on B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Agree with B. 
A. optional metrics doesn't exist in yang (the name is not being used) 
B. Correct, everything ending with * is a list. Lists with a type are leaf-lists. So where interface* [name] is a list, higher-layer-if and lower-layer-if are leaf-lists. 
C. incorrect, not even close to being possible
D. Containers -> "a container node has at most one instance", in this example interfaces and statistics are containers. that makes two, not three. 

found this very helpful : 
https://www.tail-f.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Tail-f-Instant-YANG.pdf

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. What is a characteristic of the tree?

discussion.content:
The question requires operational data so "interfaces-state" should be the first. xpath is not supported so it should be subtree

<interfaces-state xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-interfaces">
<interface>
<statistics></statistics>
</interface>
</interfaces-state>

subtree

comments.content: <name>XXX</name> is not required, it will return statistics for all interfaces.

discussion.content:
I think this is fundamentally wrong. 
To access the "statistics" container, the interface name must be provided. 

The solution should be:
 <interfaces-state xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-interfaces">
 <interface>
 <name>XXX</name>
 </interface>
 <statistics></statistics>
 </interfaces-state> 

The last option should be "subtree".

Agree with NoobChampion. 
directly from yangsuite : 
 <interfaces-state xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:yang:ietf-interfaces">
 <interface>
 <statistics/>
 </interface>
</interfaces-state>

question can't be answered because of the second missing "interface"option.
the answer on this one needs to be explored more
What should the very last one be then?
